metadata.subject: biology
metadata.dotPoint: The use of enzymes to manipulate DNA, including polymerase to synthesise DNA, ligase to join DNA and endonucleases to cut DNA. Amplification of DNA using polymerase chain reaction. The use of gel electrophoresis in sorting DNA fragments, including the interpretation of gel runs for DNA profiling

polymerase_function.name: DNA Polymerase Function
polymerase_function.formula: Synthesises new DNA strand from template
polymerase_function.correct: DNA polymerase synthesises new DNA strands by adding nucleotides complementary to a template strand. It requires a primer to start and builds in the 5' to 3' direction.

cuts DNA at specific sequences.error: Cutting is done by restriction endonucleases, not polymerase.
cuts DNA at specific sequences.fix: Polymerase builds (synthesises) new DNA. Endonuclease cuts existing DNA. Different functions entirely.
cuts DNA at specific sequences.action: Remember: Poly = many. Polymerase makes many nucleotides into a polymer chain.

joins DNA fragments together.error: Joining DNA fragments is the function of DNA ligase.
joins DNA fragments together.fix: Polymerase adds individual nucleotides to grow a strand. Ligase joins the backbones of separate fragments.
joins DNA fragments together.action: Ligase = ligation = joining. Polymerase = polymerisation = building from monomers.

translates mRNA into protein.error: Translation is performed by ribosomes, not polymerase.
translates mRNA into protein.fix: Polymerase works with nucleic acids (DNA or RNA). Ribosomes translate mRNA into protein.
translates mRNA into protein.action: Polymerase makes DNA/RNA. Ribosomes make proteins. Different molecules, different machinery.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the functions of different molecular biology enzymes.
persistent.action: Make a table: Polymerase = builds/synthesises. Ligase = joins/pastes. Endonuclease = cuts.

endonuclease_function.name: Restriction Endonuclease Function
endonuclease_function.formula: Cuts DNA at specific recognition sequences
endonuclease_function.correct: Restriction endonucleases (restriction enzymes) cut DNA at specific recognition sequences, producing either blunt ends or sticky ends with complementary single-stranded overhangs.

synthesises new DNA strands.error: DNA synthesis is done by polymerase, not endonucleases.
synthesises new DNA strands.fix: Endonucleases cut DNA. The 'nuclease' suffix means it breaks down nucleic acids.
synthesises new DNA strands.action: Endo = inside. Nuclease = breaks nucleic acids. Endonuclease = cuts inside the DNA strand.

joins DNA fragments together.error: Joining DNA is the function of ligase.
joins DNA fragments together.fix: Endonucleases cut DNA; ligase joins DNA. They have opposite functions.
joins DNA fragments together.action: In gene cloning, you cut with endonuclease first, then paste with ligase.

cuts DNA at random locations.error: Restriction enzymes cut at specific recognition sequences, not randomly.
cuts DNA at random locations.fix: Each restriction enzyme recognises a specific DNA sequence (usually 4-8 base pairs) and only cuts there.
cuts DNA at random locations.action: EcoRI always cuts at GAATTC. BamHI always cuts at GGATCC. Never random.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the specificity of restriction enzymes.
persistent.action: Each restriction enzyme has ONE specific recognition sequence. It only ever cuts at that sequence.

ligase_function.name: DNA Ligase Function
ligase_function.formula: Joins DNA fragments by forming phosphodiester bonds
ligase_function.correct: DNA ligase joins DNA fragments by forming covalent phosphodiester bonds between the sugar-phosphate backbones, permanently sealing nicks in the DNA strand.

cuts DNA at specific sequences.error: Cutting DNA is done by endonucleases, not ligase.
cuts DNA at specific sequences.fix: Ligase ligates (joins). Endonuclease cuts. They have opposite functions in the cloning process.
cuts DNA at specific sequences.action: Ligase = ligation = tying together. Like a ligament connects bones.

synthesises new DNA strands from templat.error: Synthesis of new strands is done by polymerase.
synthesises new DNA strands from templat.fix: Polymerase builds new strands nucleotide by nucleotide. Ligase just connects existing fragments.
synthesises new DNA strands from templat.action: Ligase seals gaps between fragments. Polymerase creates new genetic material.

forms hydrogen bonds between bases.error: Ligase forms covalent bonds in the backbone, not hydrogen bonds between bases.
forms hydrogen bonds between bases.fix: Base pairs form hydrogen bonds naturally. Ligase fixes the sugar-phosphate backbone with covalent phosphodiester bonds.
forms hydrogen bonds between bases.action: The backbone break is a missing covalent bond between nucleotides. Ligase restores this bond.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the type of bond that ligase creates.
persistent.action: Ligase forms covalent phosphodiester bonds between the 3'-OH and 5'-phosphate of adjacent nucleotides in the backbone.

pcr_process.name: PCR Process
pcr_process.correct: PCR amplifies DNA through repeated cycles of: denaturation (separating strands at ~95°C), annealing (primers bind at ~55°C), and elongation (Taq polymerase extends primers at ~72°C).

occurs at a constant temperature.error: PCR requires temperature cycling through three distinct phases.
occurs at a constant temperature.fix: Each step needs a different temperature. That's why PCR uses a thermal cycler machine.
occurs at a constant temperature.action: High temp (95°C) separates strands. Low temp (55°C) allows primer binding. Medium (72°C) for synthesis.

produces RNA copies from DNA.error: PCR produces DNA copies, not RNA.
produces RNA copies from DNA.fix: PCR is DNA replication in a test tube. Transcription (not PCR) makes RNA from DNA.
produces RNA copies from DNA.action: PCR uses DNA polymerase (Taq), which synthesises DNA, not RNA.

requires only a single cycle to work.error: PCR needs many repeated cycles for effective amplification.
requires only a single cycle to work.fix: Each cycle doubles the DNA amount. 30 cycles = 2^30 = over 1 billion copies from one starting molecule.
requires only a single cycle to work.action: The power of PCR is exponential amplification: 2, 4, 8, 16, 32... through repeated cycling.

persistent.gap: You don't understand PCR temperature cycling.
persistent.action: Memorise the three temperatures: 95°C (denature), 55°C (anneal primers), 72°C (extend). Repeat 25-35 times.

taq_polymerase.name: Taq Polymerase
taq_polymerase.correct: Taq polymerase is a heat-stable DNA polymerase isolated from the thermophilic bacterium Thermus aquaticus. It functions optimally at ~72°C and survives the 95°C denaturation step.

denatures and stops working at 95°C.error: Taq polymerase survives 95°C because it evolved in a hot spring bacterium.
denatures and stops working at 95°C.fix: Taq's optimal temperature is ~72°C, but it's stable at 95°C. This is why it's essential for PCR.
denatures and stops working at 95°C.action: Thermus aquaticus lives in hot springs at 70-80°C. Its enzymes evolved to handle extreme heat.

is identical to human DNA polymerase.error: Human DNA polymerase would denature during the PCR denaturation step.
is identical to human DNA polymerase.fix: Human DNA polymerase works at 37°C (body temperature). Taq works at 72°C and survives 95°C.
is identical to human DNA polymerase.action: Before Taq, scientists had to add fresh enzyme after every cycle. Taq revolutionised PCR.

synthesises RNA molecules.error: Taq is a DNA polymerase, not RNA polymerase.
synthesises RNA molecules.fix: Taq synthesises DNA. RNA polymerase (a different enzyme) makes RNA.
synthesises RNA molecules.action: PCR copies DNA to make more DNA. It uses DNA polymerase, not RNA polymerase.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why Taq polymerase is essential for PCR.
persistent.action: PCR needs high temperatures for denaturation. Only heat-stable polymerases like Taq can survive this.

gel_electrophoresis.name: Gel Electrophoresis
gel_electrophoresis.formula: DNA moves toward +; smaller fragments travel further
gel_electrophoresis.correct: Gel electrophoresis separates DNA fragments by size. DNA is negatively charged (due to phosphates) so it moves toward the positive anode. Smaller fragments move faster and further through the gel matrix.

DNA moves toward the negative cathode.error: DNA is negatively charged, so it moves toward the positive electrode.
DNA moves toward the negative cathode.fix: Opposites attract. Negative DNA is repelled by the negative cathode and attracted to the positive anode.
DNA moves toward the negative cathode.action: Phosphate groups in the DNA backbone carry negative charges. These are attracted to the positive electrode.

larger fragments travel further through.error: Smaller fragments travel further; larger ones are slowed by the gel matrix.
larger fragments travel further through.fix: The gel matrix is like a sieve. Small pieces slip through easily; large pieces get stuck and move slowly.
larger fragments travel further through.action: Think of running through a dense forest. Small animals move faster than elephants.

separates DNA based on electrical charge.error: All DNA fragments have similar charge-to-mass ratios; separation is by size.
separates DNA based on electrical charge.fix: DNA fragments differ primarily in size, not charge ratio. Size determines how easily they move through the gel.
separates DNA based on electrical charge.action: More base pairs = bigger fragment = moves more slowly through the gel matrix.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how gel electrophoresis separates DNA.
persistent.action: Key principles: DNA is negative (moves to +), gel is a sieve (small = fast = far), size determines position.

dna_profiling_strs.name: Short Tandem Repeats
dna_profiling_strs.formula: STRs vary in repeat number between individuals
dna_profiling_strs.correct: DNA profiling uses short tandem repeats (STRs) - repetitive DNA sequences in non-coding regions that vary in length between individuals. Different people have different numbers of repeats at each locus.

analyses protein-coding genes.error: DNA profiling uses non-coding repetitive regions, not protein-coding genes.
analyses protein-coding genes.fix: STRs are in non-coding DNA. They can vary between individuals without affecting protein function.
analyses protein-coding genes.action: Coding regions are too conserved (similar between people). Non-coding regions show more variation.

produces identical patterns for everyone.error: STR patterns are unique to each individual (except identical twins).
produces identical patterns for everyone.fix: The number of repeats varies between individuals. Different loci, different repeat counts = unique profile.
produces identical patterns for everyone.action: That's why it's called DNA fingerprinting - profiles are as unique as fingerprints.

requires sequencing the entire genome.error: Only specific STR loci are analysed, not the whole genome.
requires sequencing the entire genome.fix: DNA profiling checks 9-13 specific STR loci. This provides enough variation for unique identification.
requires sequencing the entire genome.action: Full genome sequencing is expensive and slow. STR analysis is fast, cheap, and sufficient.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what makes DNA profiles unique.
persistent.action: STRs = repeating units (like CATCATCAT). Number of repeats varies between people. Multiple loci checked.

forensic_paternity.name: Forensic and Paternity Applications
forensic_paternity.formula: Complete match for forensics; inherit bands from parents for paternity
forensic_paternity.correct: Forensic DNA profiling matches crime scene DNA to suspects - all loci must match. Paternity testing shows that a child has bands inherited from both parents (half from each).

partial matches are sufficient for convi.error: Forensic cases require complete matches at all tested loci.
partial matches are sufficient for convi.fix: All tested loci must match between crime scene sample and suspect. Partial matches could be coincidental.
partial matches are sufficient for convi.action: More loci tested = lower probability of random match. Courts require virtual certainty.

children have identical profiles to thei.error: Children have a unique combination of bands from both parents.
children have identical profiles to thei.fix: Each child inherits one allele from each parent at each locus. The combination is unique to that child.
children have identical profiles to thei.action: Half the child's bands match mother, half match father. The combination is not identical to either parent.

only one STR locus is needed for identif.error: Multiple loci are needed for reliable identification.
only one STR locus is needed for identif.fix: One locus might match between unrelated people by chance. Many loci together are statistically unique.
only one STR locus is needed for identif.action: USA uses 20 loci. Australia uses 9. More loci = greater discrimination = higher certainty.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how DNA profiles are interpreted.
persistent.action: Forensics: complete match required. Paternity: child's bands must all come from biological parents.

enzymes.title: Applying DNA Enzyme Concepts
enzymes.instructions: Apply your understanding of DNA manipulation enzymes.

sentences.text: To insert a human gene into a bacterial plasmid, both the gene and plasmid must first be cut with the same {{d1}} to produce compatible {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Same enzyme = same recognition sequence = compatible ends.

d2.tooltip: Sticky ends can base pair for easier ligation.

sentences.text: After the gene and plasmid fragments are aligned, {{d3}} is used to join their backbones, creating a {{d4}} plasmid.

d3.tooltip: Ligase seals the nicks in the sugar-phosphate backbone.

d4.tooltip: Recombinant DNA contains sequences from different sources.

sentences.text: Reverse transcriptase synthesises {{d5}} from an {{d6}} template, which is useful for expressing eukaryotic genes in bacteria.

d5.tooltip: cDNA = complementary DNA made from mRNA.

d6.tooltip: Reverse transcription goes RNA -> DNA (opposite of normal).

sentences.text: During the {{d1}} step at approximately 55°C, short DNA sequences called {{d2}} bind to complementary regions flanking the target sequence.

d2.tooltip: Primers are short synthetic DNA sequences (15-25 nucleotides).

sentences.text: During elongation at approximately {{d3}}°C, Taq polymerase extends the primers by adding nucleotides in the {{d4}} direction.

d3.tooltip: 72°C is optimal for Taq polymerase activity.

d4.tooltip: All DNA polymerases synthesise in the 5' to 3' direction.

sentences.text: Each PCR cycle {{d5}} the amount of target DNA, so after 30 cycles approximately {{d6}} copies are produced.

d5.tooltip: Exponential amplification: 2^n where n = number of cycles.

electrophoresis.title: Applying Gel Electrophoresis Concepts
electrophoresis.instructions: Apply your understanding of gel electrophoresis.

sentences.text: DNA samples are loaded into {{d1}} at one end of the gel near the {{d2}} electrode, and migrate toward the opposite electrode when current is applied.

d1.tooltip: Wells are small depressions molded into the gel for sample loading.

d2.tooltip: DNA starts at negative (cathode) and moves toward positive (anode).

sentences.text: A DNA ladder containing fragments of known {{d3}} is run alongside samples to allow {{d4}} of unknown fragment sizes.

d3.tooltip: Ladder fragments have precisely known base pair lengths.

d4.tooltip: Compare unknown bands to ladder bands at same position.

sentences.text: After electrophoresis, DNA can be visualised using {{d5}} dyes that bind to DNA and {{d6}} under UV light.

d5.tooltip: Ethidium bromide or SYBR Safe are common fluorescent DNA dyes.

d6.tooltip: The dye fluoresces (emits light) when bound to DNA and exposed to UV.

profiling.title: Applying DNA Profiling Concepts
profiling.instructions: Apply your understanding of DNA profiling.

sentences.text: Before STR analysis, DNA from crime scenes or biological samples is typically {{d1}} using PCR because the initial sample is often very {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: PCR produces enough DNA for reliable analysis.

d2.tooltip: Crime scene samples may contain only a few cells.

sentences.text: Different countries analyse different numbers of STR loci; larger populations require {{d3}} loci to ensure profiles are statistically {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: More people = need more distinguishing power.

d4.tooltip: More loci = lower probability of random match.

sentences.text: In forensic investigations, the DNA profile from the crime scene must {{d5}} match the suspect's profile at all tested loci for a {{d6}} to be supported.

d5.tooltip: All tested loci must match; partial matches are insufficient.

d6.tooltip: DNA evidence must be conclusive to support conviction.

enzymes.title: Mastering DNA Enzyme Concepts
enzymes.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of DNA manipulation enzymes.

sentences.text: The three key enzymes used in gene cloning have complementary functions: {{d1}} to cut DNA, {{d2}} to copy DNA, and {{d3}} to join DNA fragments.

d1.tooltip: Endonuclease = molecular scissors for cutting DNA.

d3.tooltip: Ligase = molecular glue for joining fragments.

sentences.text: Scientists often use two different restriction enzymes (double digestion) to ensure the gene inserts in the correct {{d4}} and to prevent the vector from {{d5}} without an insert.

d4.tooltip: Different ends on each side = only one correct direction for insertion.

d5.tooltip: Non-compatible ends prevent the vector from closing back on itself.

sentences.text: Blunt end ligation is less efficient than sticky end ligation because there are no {{d6}} overhangs to help position and temporarily hold the fragments together before ligase acts.

d6.tooltip: Sticky ends base pair first, positioning fragments for ligation.

sentences.text: Primers are essential for PCR because DNA polymerase can only add nucleotides to an existing {{d1}} end and cannot initiate synthesis from {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Polymerase adds to the 3' end, building the chain 5' to 3'.

d2.tooltip: DNA polymerases require a primer to provide the initial 3'-OH.

sentences.text: The specificity of PCR comes from the {{d3}} sequences, which determine exactly which {{d4}} gets amplified from a complex mixture of DNA.

d3.tooltip: Primers bind only to their complementary sequences.

d4.tooltip: Only the region between primer binding sites is amplified.

sentences.text: Before Taq polymerase was discovered, PCR required adding fresh {{d5}} after each denaturation step because regular polymerases were {{d6}} at high temperatures.

d6.tooltip: Denaturation at 95°C permanently inactivates non-thermostable enzymes.

electrophoresis.title: Mastering Gel Electrophoresis Concepts
electrophoresis.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of gel electrophoresis.

sentences.text: The gel matrix acts as a molecular {{d1}}, allowing small fragments to pass through while {{d2}} larger fragments, resulting in size-based separation.

d1.tooltip: The gel pores filter DNA based on size, like a sieve.

d2.tooltip: Large fragments have more difficulty navigating through the gel matrix.

sentences.text: Higher percentage agarose gels have {{d3}} pores and are better for resolving {{d4}} DNA fragments.

d3.tooltip: More agarose = tighter mesh = smaller pores.

d4.tooltip: Small fragments need small pores to see size differences between them.

sentences.text: DNA fragments of identical size from different samples will migrate to the same {{d5}} on the gel, allowing direct {{d6}} between samples run in adjacent lanes.

d5.tooltip: Same size = same distance from wells = same horizontal position.

d6.tooltip: Bands at the same level indicate fragments of equal size.

profiling.title: Mastering DNA Profiling Concepts
profiling.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of DNA profiling.

sentences.text: STRs are useful for DNA profiling because they are highly {{d1}} between individuals while being inherited in a predictable {{d2}} pattern.

d1.tooltip: Polymorphic = many forms. Different people have different alleles.

d2.tooltip: One allele from each parent, following Mendel's laws.

sentences.text: The probability of two unrelated individuals having identical profiles at 13 loci is approximately one in several {{d3}}, making DNA profiling highly {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Multiple independent loci compound the probability.

d4.tooltip: Can distinguish between virtually any two individuals.

sentences.text: Identical twins present a challenge for DNA profiling because they share the same {{d5}} and therefore have {{d6}} STR profiles.

d5.tooltip: Identical twins develop from one fertilised egg = same DNA.

d6.tooltip: Same genome = same STR alleles at all loci.
